Inventions / accomplishments: First African-American department chair at Harvard Medical School
Invented a method of fabricating an imaging X-ray spectrometer
Put forth the Andrews–Curtis conjecture in group theory with Morton L. Curtis, still unsolved
Responsible for the construction of many roads and bridges, including the Whitehurst Freeway, the Tidal Basin Bridge, and an extension to the Baltimore-Washington Parkway.
Folding bed (debatable - another source says it was Sarah Goode in 1885.)
Extracted chaulmoogra oil for the treatment of Hansen's disease (leprosy)

Constructed wooden clock; astronomer; assisted in the survey of the original boundaries of the District of Columbia; authored a series of almanacs and ephemerides; naturalist: recorded observations on emergences of periodical cicadas and on the behavior of honey bees.
Work on diffeomorphisms and symplectomorphisms
First African-American woman to receive a patent for a web-based software invention, LinkLine, an Equal Employment Opportunity case management and tracking software

First African-American female physician to receive a patent for a medical invention; inventions relate to cataract surgery and include the Laserphaco Probe, which revolutionized the industry in the 1980s, and an ultrasound technique for treatment

Occupation(s): Farmer, carpenter, blacksmith, railroad worker, businessman, inventor
Inventions / accomplishments: Janney coupler improvements; invented the car device #594,059 dated November 23, 1897; rotary engine patent #478,271 dated July 5, 1892
Invented chair with sliding skin (2004) and the quantitative display apparatus (2005)
Invented "Gong and Signal Chair for Hotels"; second African-American woman to receive a patent
Gastroscope pioneer
Probability theory and Markov chain theorist
Brain tumor surgery and research

First proposed the Blackwell channel model used in coding theory and information theory; one of the eponyms of the Rao–Blackwell theorem, which is a process that significantly improves crude statistical estimators
Second black inventor to issue a patent; invented seed planter and cotton planter.
Silicon retina able to process images in the same manner as a living retina
Ironing board allowing sleeves of women's garments to be ironed more easily
First African-American to receive a PhD in any subject; received physics doctorate from Yale University in 1876
Pathologist and geneticist; Professor Emeritus Pritzker School of Medicine; first tenured African-American professor at the University of Chicago Division of Biological Sciences
Artificial heart pacemaker control unit
Published three scholarly abstracts in Science; collaborated on a paper published in the Journal of Industrial and Engineering Chemistry
Protein structure research
Street sweeper truck and a type of paper punch
Invented fire safe
Received a patent for an improved horseshoe[46]
Invented the home security system
Rotary-blade lawn mower patent

Led a group of engineers who developed the Tactical Optical Fiber Connector (TOFC), the first fiber optic connector deployed under battlefield conditions, and the ST Connector that helped make fiber optic communications affordable.
Sickle cell anemia studies; in October 1937 he published "Immunologic Studies in Sickle Cell Anemia" in the Archives of Internal Medicine; many of the findings are still valid today
Pediatric neurosurgery at Johns Hopkins University; first surgeon to successfully separate craniopagus twins
Invented ultraviolet camera/spectrograph, which was used by NASA when it launched Apollo 16 in 1972
Discovered hundreds of uses for previously useless vegetables and fruits, principally the peanut

Occupation(s): Electrician, construction, international businessman, and aviation pioneer
Inventions / accomplishments: Designed long-distance flight airplane; the only African-American to invent and display the airplane at the 1911 First Industrial Air Show held in conjunction with the Auto Show at Grand Central Palace in Manhattan in New York City; president of the African Union Company, Inc.
Valuable contributions to several fields: medicine, biology, food science, and astrochemistry
Conducted 1940s experiments using dolls to study children's attitudes about race
First Black president of the American Psychological Association
Heating, ventilation, and air conditioning; received some 40 US patents relating to HVAC systems
Organic ionogen for aluminum electrolytic capacitors, cationic dialdehyde polysaccharides for wet strength paper and others, US Patent Office US Pat #3609467 US Pat #3547423 and others
Expert on jellyfish hydrodynamics and designer of a vertical-axis wind farm adapted from schooling fish
First black American woman with a PhD in chemistry
Led the team that developed the ISA bus, and led the design team responsible for creating the first one-gigahertz computer processor chip
Developed improved techniques for blood storage

Explorer; first modern European outsider to confirm the existence of gorillas, and later the Pygmy people of central Africa; identified as white throughout life, but his mother was a Réunionnais mulatto; settled in America and considered it his country by adoption; the full aspects of his ancestry were not uncovered until 1979, and are still little known today
Work at the Lewis Research Center of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and its predecessor, the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics
First African American with a PhD in computer science; software inventor including OfficeTalk at Xerox PARC
Drag racing engineer and driver
Chemistry doctorate, first received (1943, University of California, Berkeley)
Inequality studies
Work on supersymmetry, supergravity, and superstring theory
Cabinet bed invention; first African-American woman to receive a patent in the United States
Awarded the first Presidential Endowed Chair at Clemson University in honor of his accomplishments
The first African-American professor at Harvard, Boston dentist, and inventor of a wooden golf tee.
Specializes in syntax and the study of African American English
Amputee self-feeding device
Co-discovered Rutherfordium (element 104) and Dubnium (element 105) at Lawrence Livermore Laboratory
Inventor at Bell Laboratories

IBM's 1st black Distinguished Engineer and 2nd black IBM Fellow. Inventor of several software engineering techniques including system and methods for locating mobile devices using location and presence information
Co-inventor of imaging x-ray spectrometer.
NASA's first black female engineer

Helped develop technologies leading to the invention of the touch-tone telephone, portable fax, solar cells, fiber optic cables, and the technology enabling caller ID and call waiting.[citation needed] However, in a recent article from MIT, there is no evidence that she helped to develop these technologies.[82]
Duke University neuroscience bird songs studies
First African American to be granted a patent (for a dry cleaning process called dry scouring)
Held patent for improvements to the bicycle frame, specifically so it could be taken apart for compact storage
Invented Super Soaker while researching thermal energy transfer engines; worked with NASA; holder of over 80 patents
Made contributions to the United States' aeronautics and space programs with the early application of digital electronic computers at NASA.
Invented refrigerated truck systems
First to synthesize the natural product physostigmine; earned 130 chemical patents; lauded for humanitarian achievements

Occupation(s): Woods Hole Marine Biology Institute biologist
Inventions / accomplishments: Provided basic and initial descriptions of the structure–function–property relationship of the plasma membrane of biological cells
Work in tracing the ancestry of African Americans via DNA testing
Organ transplantation pioneer, particularly renal transplant research and surgery; author or co-author of 172 articles in scientific publications

Worked as a draftsman for both Alexander Graham Bell and Thomas Edison; became a member of Edison's Pioneers and served as an expert witness in many light bulb litigation lawsuits; said to have invented the water closet
Designer of Fairchild Channel F, the first programmable ROM cartridge-based video game console

Paul and Aileen Russell Professor, Pritzker School of Medicine; MacArthur Fellow, Searle Scholar, founder and chairman, Avocet Polymer Technologies, Inc.; founder and chairman, Renacyte BioMolecular Technologies, Inc; discovered use of surfactant copolymers as molecular chaperones to augment endogenous injury repair mechanisms of living cells; holder of many patents covering scar treatment therapies, tissue engineered ligaments, brain trauma therapies, and protective garments[citation needed]
Teacher at West Tennessee University
First African American to study and work as a professionally trained nurse in the United States[112]
Shoe assembly Machine
His discoveries allowed chemists around the world to create inexpensive peroxide compounds
Invented a version of the automatic lubricator for steam engines, McCoy learned a great deal of his skills from a mechanical apprenticeship when he was age fifteen .
Specializes in the study of creole language formation
Designed a steam operated propeller to provide propulsion to boats in shallow water
First African American woman to earn a PhD in Physics (University of Michigan Ann Arbor 1972) on vibrational analysis of secondary chlorides

Invented an early version of a gas mask called a smoke hood, and created the first traffic light that included a third "warning" position which is standard today. Morgan also developed a chemical that was used in hair products for hair-straightening.
Invented electric elevator doors that automatically open and close
Studies toxic metals in the environment; supporter of the lead poisoning thesis of the decline of the Roman Empire
Inventions in oil refining
Furnace for Central Heating
Work on the epidemiology of tropical diseases, including malaria
Work on the mathematical physics of gravitational lensing
Manhattan Project, worked with Albert Einstein and Enrico Fermi
Inventor of the multiple-effect evaporator
Investigated possible role of arsenic in the death of Zachary Taylor; interim president of Florida A&M University
A runner for stoops (1896), bag closure device (1898), a wrinkle-preventing trouser stretcher (1899), a garment-hanger (1903), and a holder for brooms and like articles.
Wireless communications engineer
Patent for hot comb
Economist, social theorist and political philosopher
Stereotype threat studies
President of the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics from 2000 to 2002
Security engineer at Microsoft, Mozilla, and Apple
Inventor of the toggling whaling harpoon head
Blue baby syndrome treatment in the 1940s

First person to prove that insects can hear and can distinguish pitch, that cockroaches can learn by trial and error, and that honeybees can see color; first African-American to receive a PhD from the University of Chicago
Program Director, Division of Musculoskeletal Diseases, at National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases, National Institutes of Health
Researcher and popular educator in astronomy and the sciences
Worked for NACA and NASA at Langley Research Center

Created black cosmetic products
Former chair of the National Science Board
Co-developed the foil electret microphone
Entered University of Chicago at age 13; PhD at 19; worked on the Manhattan Project; wrote over 100 scientific papers; helped recruit minorities into the sciences
The first black person on record to have successfully performed pericardium (the sac surrounding the heart) surgery to repair a wound.

Noted for her contributions to chemotherapy and for pioneering the use of the drug methotrexate to treat breast cancer and skin cancer
